title: 104_s1250
content: The Act titled "Federal Employee Compensation Protection Act of 1995" ensures civilian pay continues during periods of lapsed appropriations. The "Federal Employee Compensation Protection Act of 1995" guarantees continuance of pay for employees during periods of lapsed appropriations, defining terms like 'period of lapsed appropriations', 'employee', and 'agency'. The "Federal Employee Compensation Protection Act of 1995" defines terms like 'pay' as basic pay, premium pay, agency contributions, and other elements of compensation, and 'furlough' as placing an employee in a temporary status without duties or pay due to lack of work or funds. The "Federal Employee Compensation Protection Act of 1995" ensures that employees who are furloughed due to a lapse in appropriations will still be paid for the period of furlough. The Act appropriates necessary funds from the Treasury for employees affected by lapsed appropriations, guaranteeing their pay during the furlough period. The "Federal Employee Compensation Protection Act of 1995" ensures that employees not furloughed will be paid. It includes provisions for expenditures and defines agencies. Technical amendments are made to chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. Continuance of military pay during periods of lapsed appropriations. Amendments made to chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code to ensure pay continuity. Sec. 1015 of title 37, United States Code, ensures continuance of pay for members of the uniformed services during periods of lapsed appropriations. Appropriations are made available for the pay of members serving during such periods. Sec. 1015 of title 37, United States Code guarantees pay for uniformed service members during lapsed appropriations. Expenditures are charged to the appropriate fund once regular appropriations are passed. This provision is effective from October 1, 1995, to September 30, 1996. "Sec. 1015 of title 37, United States Code ensures pay for service members during lapsed appropriations, with expenses covered by the appropriate fund once regular appropriations are approved."
